title: Solu Corridor Transmission Line Tender Controversy
description:
The case involves allegations of corruption and procedural irregularity against then-Energy Minister Radha Kumari Gyawali and several officials of the Nepal Electricity Authority (NEA) concerning the tender for the Solu Corridor 132 kV Transmission Line Project. In 2015, the Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority (CIAA) accused the NEA board, chaired by Minister Gyawali, of acting with 'mala fide intentions' by disqualifying the lowest bidder and awarding the contract to the second-lowest bidder.

The lowest bid, from a joint venture of Jaguar Overseas Ltd and BS Ltd, was for $20.35 million. The contract was awarded to Mohan Energy Corporation for $22.97 million, creating a potential loss of $2.62 million (approximately NPR 270 million) to the state. The CIAA argued that the disqualification was based on minor technicalities that should have been clarified.

Key events included:

  • The CIAA recommending that Prime Minister Sushil Koirala take action against Minister Gyawali.
  • Prime Minister Koirala dismissing Gyawali from her post on October 1, 2015.
  • Gyawali and other accused officials challenging the CIAA's decision in the Supreme Court.

On March 16, 2016, a Supreme Court bench headed by Chief Justice Kalyan Shrestha annulled the CIAA's directives. The court's verdict effectively exonerated Gyawali and the other NEA officials, finding that the decision to disqualify the lowest bidder was based on the consultant's report and did not constitute corruption. The Parliament's Public Accounts Committee (PAC) also investigated the matter separately.
unverified_info: Initial research notes contained mentions of a case named "Chleliya" and an alleged loss amount of "55 Crore" (NPR 550 million). However, comprehensive verification against credible sources has found no evidence to support either of these details in connection with this case. All verifiable reports identify the project as the Solu Corridor Transmission Line and the potential loss as approximately NPR 27 Crore. The "55 Crore" figure is therefore considered erroneous unless primary documentation proves otherwise.
key_allegations: Irregularity in the public procurement process for the Solu Corridor 132 kV Transmission Line Project.
Awarding a construction contract to the second-lowest bidder with 'mala fide intentions'.
Causing a potential financial loss of approximately NPR 270 million ($2.62 million) to the state.
Improper disqualification of the lowest bidder based on minor, rectifiable technical issues.

Public Accounts Committee (PAC), Parliament of Nepal

timeline.title: Contract Awarded to Second-Lowest Bidder
timeline.description: The Nepal Electricity Authority (NEA) board, chaired by Energy Minister Radha Gyawali, decided to award the Solu Corridor contract to the second-lowest bidder, Mohan Energy Corporation.

timeline.title: CIAA Recommends Action Against Minister
timeline.description: The CIAA concluded its investigation, finding 'mala fide intentions' in the tender process, and recommended that the Prime Minister take action against Minister Gyawali for causing a potential loss of NPR 270 million.

timeline.title: Energy Minister Dismissed
timeline.description: Based on the CIAA's recommendation, Prime Minister Sushil Koirala dismissed Radha Gyawali from her post as Minister for Energy.

timeline.title: Supreme Court Issues Show-Cause Notice
timeline.description: In response to a writ petition filed on behalf of Gyawali, the Supreme Court issued a show-cause notice to the CIAA regarding its recommendation.

timeline.title: Supreme Court Exonerates Gyawali
timeline.description: A joint bench of Chief Justice Kalyan Shrestha and Justice Jagadish Sharma Paudel annulled the CIAA's directives, clearing Radha Gyawali and other NEA officials of the corruption allegations.

timeline.title: NEA Hands Over Contract
timeline.description: Following the Supreme Court's verdict, the Nepal Electricity Authority officially handed over the project contract to Mohan Energy Corporation.

timeline.title: Parliamentary Committee Launches Investigation
timeline.description: The Parliament's Public Accounts Committee (PAC) began its own investigation into the tender decision and temporarily ordered a halt to the project's work.
